title: Unique man with a big heart seeks compassionate woman
text:
Hello. I'm about to lay it on the line. Open and honest. And only compassionate women with a big, huge, loving heart will keep reading. If you're looking for a man with money, a man with a nice car, nice house, I'm not him.

I'm 49. I'll be 50 in August. Most people think I'm in my early- or mid-40s.I'm young at heart, playful, loving, gently teasing. I'm affectionate. I'm fiercely loyal and protective. I'm helpful, when I can be. I'm NEVER mean, or uncaring, or hateful or spiteful or abusive. That's not me.

I used to love to dance, but I haven't gone out in years. I love music (most genres), and comedy. Those 2 things have helped keep me sane, and alive, and from falling into despair. I love to laugh and to make others laugh. I can be a total goofball at times, but I'm not always. I show appropriate behavior at the appropriate times. I'm mature, without being TOO mature. My IQ is above-average (probably around 130, these days; was higher when I was younger). But I'm not a brain. I'm very much into Jeopardy!. If I had to describe myself in one word... that would be difficult. But if you held a gun to my head, I'd say... lovable. My friends say I'm likeable. 

I have more online friends than I do friends I can hang out with. I have one close friend who lives in my area, and one good, married female friend who lives over an hour away. I have a few very close but never-met-in-person online friends, male and female, who know everything about me.

I'm a type 1 diabetic. I have been for over 40 years. I have all my limbs, all my body parts work. I do not have most of the issues and symptoms that many 40-year diabetics have. And I'm holding steady. 

Years ago, I was convicted of something that I didn't do. I only tell the details of it to people who know me; people who know who I am as a person. Every single person I've ever told believes me. I'm not a criminal, not a scumbag, not a person that anybody needs to worry about, at all. But it affected my life big-time. It made it extremely difficult to get a job. When I did get offered any jobs, they were only low-paying, non-career positions. I couldn't get back into my chosen profession, and had to go into those other jobs, which was physical work. After a few years of that, my physical issues started showing up. I'm doing well enough now, but I can't do that sort of work anymore, even if I wanted to. I'm trying desperately to get back into my chosen field, but it's been so long... Companies only want people with recent work experience in that field, and/or certain experience that I don't have. I've gone to school and taken classes to keep up on my knowledge, but this hasn't helped. They want the recent work experience. Also, my age is a factor, I'm quite certain. I've had my resume critiqued and updated, several times. I've done lots of things to try... well, anyway, it hasn't helped. 

I'm broke. I'm barely scraping by. I have zero extra money. I rent a room in a small home. I don't leave the house except when I need to go to the grocery store or to a doctor's appointment, or when i do have a job interview, stuff that I need to do. And I try to lump my errands together, do them all on the same day, so that I can save gas. I don't go out with friends, don't go to the movies, nothing. I can't afford it.

I'm not looking for someone who will pay for everything. Yes, that would be nice, of course. But I don't use anybody, I don't want someone to support me, or buy me stuff. I just want someone who will understand, and... I don't know. We can go from here, if anybody is interested in learning more about me. I have a huge heart, full of love, and I'm waiting to give it, to show it. I'm lonely. Oh so lonely.

title: Searching for my best friend
text:
Perhaps one day I might come across it. Perhaps not. Perhaps the possibilities may have come and gone for me.

I wonder if the magic spark can ever come back into my life? I often think about it...from time to time. Perhaps you might be thinking the same thing.

Being in my 30s, I have to admit, I have been truly in love in my lifetime and there is nothing like it. Simply nothing. 

It's funny but, it is finding that one person that when I look at her, words are hard to come out of my mouth. When I sit next to her, there is no need for words. Simply look into her eyes and two hearts feel it without one single word. 

The most astonishing things is, when we are married, it is so easy to see that women are interested in us but, there is nothing we can do about it ....The loyal ones anyway:)When you are divorced, things are very different. The questions I ask are interesting: 

Is it over for me? 

Is it even possible to find, rediscover and feel true love again in your 30s? 

Will my heart be able to trust again? 

Me? I am a happy, grounded, and content man. It would seem that I don't really need anything in my life. BUT, there is always that 'time', when I am alone that I think to myself, "could it be different'? I am stable, secure and most weeks, there are a couple of days I get lonely and find myself reading through these posts and wonder what it would be like to meet someone for a drink and get to know each other. I think about it each week and do nothing about it. Today, I am writing my thoughts on here. 

What kind of woman do I truly adore? I love my woman to be...

- She loves to show physical affection, is romantic, playful, and emotionally available 

- She is well educated and a hard worker, financially secure

- She has high integrity and believes honesty is the only policy, his word is SOLID... She is NOT into deception

- She is spiritual or believes in God but is not a fanatic . . . 

- She longs for and craves her man to notice her and spend time with her and holds her hand. Stares into his eyes...

- She is truly compassionate and very caring 

- She is 30-early 50s (PLEASE respect my age request), Caucasian, European, Asian attractive, fit, classy, slender...... (It's what I am attracted too)

- She is 100% SINGLE and COMPLETELY over her last relationship, loyal to me.... as I am to her

- She knows how to balance a relationship between her kids, work and her man. 

- She is not afraid of commitment and is looking for a life partner...

- She doesn't have to be perfect...I am not either

She is my dream. She has been my dream for a few years however, I ask God to help me somehow, someway, bring her into my life, slowly, gently, most beautifully and most understandingly. 

If you took the time to read this dreary yet emotional outpouring, responses are not only welcome, they are desired.

Me? I am masculine, attractive, muscular, caring, low key yet passionate, financially secure, well educated and have traveled a lot both here and overseas. I am spiritual, spontaneous, non-materialistic, down-to-earth. I am into fitness and healthy living but I am not a fanatic. I would like to be a great addition to someone's life. Especially if you are close to your parents and children. My family lives out of state and sometimes, that makes things pretty hard not being around them. 

Whoever you are. . .Thank you kindly for reading. I hope I touched one heart that is in the same place as mine. Although we may never meet, there is a tiny chance, we will. If these words resonate with you and you answered 'yes, that's me', to my little wish list, then we really should chat here.

I leave you with one last thought......One heart. With so many people in this entire world, why, oh why is it SO hard to find our ONE HEART?... I don't want to give up on believing I can find you and you, me. When two hearts become one, there is NOTHING like it in our life time.

I realize my posting is long and only the kind of woman I'm looking for will actually read it and respond thoughtfully...please give me a glimpse into your intellect and spirit. Please be courteous and respond with a recent photo of your face. If I reply, my message will include the same. I will only reply if I believe there's resonance and potential compatibility at different levels. No indecent pics. Not looking for sex here, so don't waste your time sending sex requests. 

Don't believe in long distance relationships, so Please be within 30 miles of the South Bay. 

I will continue posting until I feel comfortable meeting the one. We can exchange a few emails and then plan to meet. Please put your favorite food in the subject line to weed out the robots.

title: The Conversation
text:
Have you ever had the conversation?

Have you ever connected with someone on that level where you can just pour out your innermost thoughts, ambitions, fears, fantasies, secrets and know that they will not judge you for it. Just get it all out there, ya know? I think we all have things we have never told anyone else, perhaps things we are not proud of, or things that we know others might disagree with. And it seems like the closer we get to a person, the harder it can be to tell them these things, for fear of rejection or disapproval. Why rock the boat, right?

Yet I desire nothing less than a totally open and honest relationship. Where we have that conversation early and often until there's nothing left to tell and we know eachother from the bottom up, for better or worse. And if that's the goal, how do we get there?

Its kind of scary actually. I mean I consider myself very open minded and non judgemental in most ways so I think i could handle most anything my partner tells me if done in a spirit of trust. but the only woman i was ever in love with certainly could not have had that conversation with me. Neither end of it. I know she couldn't have divulged her inner secrets and would've freaked out about mine. So clearly an honest relationship requires that both participants WANT to have the conversation and are able to keep an open mind and accept the other person's flaws or differences of opinion.

In the past, when I have been attracted to a woman, I have been too fearful of "saying the wrong thing" to try and have the conversation early on. Now I know that was a mistake.

It is easiest to have the conversation with a near stranger. If the other person can't deal with what you have to say, then that is their problem. You have much less invested in the relationship at that point, so if they want to bailout because you opened up, fine.. So it makes sense to have the conversation sooner rather than later. Even starting with the first date. "tell me one thing you've never told anyone else, and I'll tell you one of mine".

Or it could be held with a pen-pal, met through CL for example. But the danger here is that the other person may simply stop writing, and it kinda sucks to be halfway done pouring your heart out after 2 weeks of correspondence and then pffft.... bye bye. But there is risk in everything I guess.

I look around me at the couples I know and I wonder how many of them have ever had the conversation. Not many I bet.

I'd love to hear your thoughts and experiences. Have you had the conversation? why or why not? If you did, what was it like and do you feel it helped your relationship? Would you even WANT to have the conversation? Would you be able to divulge your most closely guarded secrets either to someone you trust, or to a stranger? Do you dare?

I'm all ears.

---

If you've made it this far, you may wish to know a little more about me. So, the basics: professional, swm, 5'9", fit, non-smoker, drink rarely, no kids or crazy ex, no debt. The rest, you'll just have to reply to find out.

title: Married for married and the unbearable lightness of being
text:
Greetings. I'm searching for a married woman with whom to share lighthearted fun, fulfill a need for emotional and physical intimacy and re-experience romance and the feelings of being desired. Since these posts by married men are pretty common, I'll make the distinguishing comment that I am in an open relationship after 23 years of marriage. And this is my first time out looking for a lover. I am a kindhearted, decent man who's taking an unconventional route to maintain a happy life. And that life has to include intimacy with a loving woman. I think it's realistic to assume that what I'm seeking could only be realized with a married woman who is equally committed to her own marriage and home situation as I am. She just needs an oasis from her married life where she can spend time with a man who will make her feel special and with whom she can share a deep emotional and physical connection. The relationship could be long term, but not as life partners.

So now I'll tell you about myself. I am an artist, a photographer, a technologist and an occasional journalist. I'm interested in all kinds of subjects and engage my interests with focused enthusiasm. I hold a very progressive worldview and am interested in politics, civil rights, art, digital privacy as a human right and any form of constructive expression that shakes things up. I'm very direct and honest in my interactions with people and always try act with integrity and expect that from others. My straightforwardness comes from a place of caring. I have a dry, irreverent sense of humor that is essential to who I am. I am bold and confident with people but tend to choose time alone over time with people. Alone time is essential to my creative process and health. My best work has come from the time that I spend in contemplation.

So here's what am I looking for in a woman. I'm 53, so it would be best if you are 40 to early 50's so we both have enough life experience to be able to have a connection. I'm attracted to bright, creative, strong women. I assume that being well educated would come along with that. I'm looking for a woman who I can really talk to, not just be physical with. I want to be able to have engaging conversations about the things we are mutually interested in. It's really important to me that you be very comfortable with expressing affection, something which is painfully missing from my life and which I need to express as well. I want us to feel really good and relaxed with each other -- have a genuine connection -- with friendship, romantic and sexual components. I don't have a ready list of physical requirements. So much of attraction comes from what's inside. That's not to say that looks don't count -- there has to be some raw physical attraction. It's just that it's subjective -- beauty is in the eye of the beholder. To be in my own comfort zone, I'd prefer a woman who no taller than 5'8 (I am about 5'6) , has normal build (I'm not into big women, though curves are great ) and goes light on cosmetics.

As far as my own appearance goes -- many sweet confused people have mistaken me for the director of E.T., particularly when am out with my camera, wearing a NY stickball cap and round glasses. I've even posed for photos -- no autographs so far. I'm about the same height as the former host of the Daily Show. (BTW, I'm not using names to keep this post out of the grips of search engines). I'm slim and have "distinguished" gray hair ;-) I have a substantial libido (as far as I know) and need the mystery woman to have robust sexual appetite as well. I'm very open minded about sex -- no judgements. But not every activity is right for everyone. I'm open to safe, sane, *mutually* consensual experimentation. We have to establish trust and a real connection before the sex can happen.

Interested? Let's start by exchanging a few emails. It's really important that your response reveal enough about you and what you're looking for in order for me figure out if we have enough in common to go a little further. Please, no one paragraph generic responses. I'll just end up asking you to tell me more. If the connection seems promising then I'll trade non-salacious photos with you. Then we can meet at a cafe in S.F. and see what's up. I'm not going to overthink this and expect to know the full you (or you to know the full me) based on a couple emails or even a first meeting. For practical reasons you need to live in SF. I can't travel to you.

I hope you've found this personal ad to be open, honest and appealing. I look forward to your response.

Me

p.s. The Unbearable Lightness of Being is one of my favorite movies and apropos to the topic of this personal ad.

title: Get flooded easily? Brain too sensitive? Wizard rather than muggle?
text:
Do you also get "flooded" easily with certain types of input? Like a loud café or obnoxious people/sounds, and experience real discomfort as a result? 

Are your ways of receiving, feeling, and processing outside data different from how it computes to others?

Like, they don't gauge correctly in what they do or say in terms of what works for you? That maybe they don't have the sensitivity, brain mechanisms, synapses, etc. for even processing like you do?

Do you feel you're highly sensitive, and even to subtle things and that compared to you, most people are relative clods (not meaning disrespect)?

Do you find that you have ways of coping with these issues? Think the world is made up of narcissists? 

Do you relate to the Xmen/mutants versus regular homo sapiens, the wizards vs muggles? There are legions more muggles than wizards - millions to one perhaps. 

As a result, do you feel you have to attend to your "special needs", so to speak? Either to instruct people how to treat you (if you think they're worth the investment) or to dismiss the clods as clods and don't allow their insensitivity to touch you?

Do you easily feel misunderstood and even abused when you hang out with people who have no clue, no similar wiring, or curious nature to find out? Do you easily then feel victimized by those who do those things?

It would be grand if we lived in a world that was more sensitive, more complexly wired, and i think more of us ultra-sensitive types need to inform others how to make it so, as they have no clue. But finding one another would be great first step!

Have you been told you're 'special' (as in: really special!), maybe assisted by being really, really attractive?

If you answer yes to most of these questions, we have A LOT IN COMMON. Write.

title: Gamer guy looking for Gamer gal
text:
Hello, my name is Jason, and I'm a nerd. 

I'm a partial insomniac, and I can read more books in a week than most people can watch sitcoms on TV in the same time. 

I consider myself an all-round gamer, but have social skills enough to convince upstanding parents that I'm a respectable fellow...

I know enough about computers to deal well, but I could however identify every animal we could see on a hike. I can also quote movies that I like with robot-like precision. 

I have a bonfire in my backyard every once in a while to get together with friends and geek-out out well as cook-out. 

I love rum, hate gin, and wish I could be a pirate instead of a ninja. I think liquor should be sipped, not pounded, and I am secure enough in my manhood to drink delicious pink girly drinks and enjoy them.

For physical description...well, best be honest. I'm 10 inches over five feet, I have long brown hair (though I'm thinking of shaving it off), and blue eyes. I usually go about with some chin hair, but when winter comes, I go grizzly-Adams if I don't have anyone to tell me they don't like it.

I'm about 200lbs. So yes, I have a bit of pudge, but I am not obese (according to the government anyway). I hate exercise for its own sake...It's so boring. So yup, all in all, just a regular average guy. Wanna be my gym partner?

My idea of a first date involves going to Starbucks for coffee to make sure neither of us are kidney-stealers or serial killers or some such, then maybe mini-golf, or a quiet pub and some delicious bacon-cheese fries.

If it went to a "real date" it would be a nice dinner and then random evening activity of her choice....movie, hike, or just relaxing on a couch with drinks, watching some good Sci-Fi or something.

Anyway. I am basically looking for a cute lady who can nerd it up with me, whether it be video games or D&D, and while I am admittedly a complete horndog, I want just one perfect woman who I can lavish my praise and attentions on.

I would like someone who likes things similar to I, who can trade witticisms blow-for-blow with my friends, but who can pretend to be demure enough to let me take care of her when I need to feel more manly ;) 

A good sense of humor is a must. If you can't laugh during a tragedy, you might as well be dead!

You should enjoy a good scotch, and the ability to quote Monty Python and Mel Brooks is a plus!

So, if you like what you read, or at least aren't screaming for the hills, send me a message :)

title: If you just believe...
text:
Fears and insanity and the anticipation of loss are sometimes insatiable, silent manias. There is no absolute cessation but there is fluctuation; a rise, a fall. Wind lifts and chimes like tinsel at windows audibly twinkle; wind diminishes and chimes hang resting. So, too, do your fears and insecurities and insanities and hesitancies lift and diminish. The most you can ask in a partner, you can find in a wind chime: that it offers a way to measure, that it stay regardless.

You realize that your interactions do not have to vacillate between periods of excess and depletion. You are enough such that, on rainy nights, you do not require every moment from someone else, that being alone is not absolute abandonment. You understand the amount of space you need for yourself in order to be better for someone else. You also know that there are moments in which you want all of a person. There are other moments in which they need all of you. Weaknesses and vulnerabilities are no longer liabilities. You feel like more of what you want to see in yourself when you see that you can, perhaps for the first time, be strong enough so that another person looks to you and is not disappointed. 

Being comfortable in your own skin allows you to best determine whose skin it is most compatible with. Your awareness of that vessel of your subjectivity, that previously fickle and ambiguous bundle of nerves you live in, learns slowly by comparison. You experience the bodies of others and, in their weight and warmth and texture, determine slowly as you get older, by process of elimination, which you prefer--too light, too rough, too cool, too heavy, too smooth, too light--until you find a type that seems to suit you, to electrify that object in which you reside. 

You look for the value in other people and often you find it. If you force yourself to look for the best in others, you may eventually exhaust yourself making excuses. You may interpret the reactions of others as malicious, but most of the time you will be wrong and you will know this. The aloofness or unkindness or disregard you experience is only a reciprocation of some other event. And, yes, you know the difference between naïveté and hopefulness. You also know that those injured by the former often abandon the latter. Maybe you have been hurt in the past, maybe profoundly, but it is not worse than you could handle, not worse than any one other person has handled, so you cling near-breathless at times to the idea that all people are, somewhere within themselves, generally good, those better versions of themselves. You bend a bit when you have to, you look harder, you know: no one can do better than from where he is standing in this instant. Just as you can do no better than from where you are standing in this instant. This prevents you from cynicism, from abandoning an empathy that is not lost but is occasionally misplaced. You trust your judgment enough. As with everything, in this you will sometimes, perhaps often, be wrong. Learn something about this, learn to be more wary, of your judgment, of others. Conclude that if you err in judgment because something gorgeous in someone led you to give them the benefit of the doubt, you are where you ought to be and this is hardly a flaw in you. 

You digest the fact that yours is not the worst or the first or the last time happening of some particular thing. You remember a design you drew when you were younger, something about lines and years in which your younger self held your older self to standards that then seemed reasonable but now are less than logical: marriage by a certain age, what the spouse was supposed to resemble, letters to attach to the end of your name, where you were to live and in which type of house, what you would drive, how many kids would be in the back seat. It is obtrusive almost, and embarrassing, that you have perhaps disappointed your younger self but this is not actually the case. Your younger self had a limited notion of what would make you happy now. The older you knows, from this point of reference, what actualizes this happiness, how the version by the younger is adapted to your circumstances. Even if it seems occasionally out of reach, it can be seen from where you stand. The younger you though you should change the world; the older you knows better than to overestimate your own abilities, your power to move and manipulate things outside of yourself. You also, and more hesitantly, let go of that harbored notion that perhaps the world will change you. You stop waiting for redemption and opt for urgency. 

You do not consider fairy tales any longer, keeping in mind that children leave bread crumbs in the woods because they know no better. You stop clinging to the urban myths of perfection, those imposed notions of how things are supposed to look at this or any age, realizing that these too are derived from little more than fantasy, those perfect ironies and averted tragedies that worked out best for all involved. They always seem to happen to a friend of a friend. Instead, you start to write your own stories, the nostalgic narratives of how you see things having worked out. You are not the hero of your own story, sometimes your story does not have a hero, some times the hero fails. You are the only way you remember, flawed though this remembering may be. As a result, you most vividly recollect the nascent stages of any relationship, even those with the most heart- and gut-wrenching endings. You feel that you are okay for where you are in your life if most of your memories are lovelier versions of themselves, of the people in them. 

The undeniably selfish part of you and the undeniably frightened part of you want the same thing but for different reasons: to be seen by someone else the way that, in your best, bravest, most hopeful moments, you see yourself, that best version of yourself realized. The child you were and the adult you are intersect and you often worry about which you identify with more closely. You look for someone that sees you through both sets of your own eyes: from the child, as a set of limitless possibilities, from the adult, as an aware and aspiring being, pensive but not paralyzed. You may find that bridges have already been built, that walls crumble with little force. This, you are able to say to yourself finally, is all very navigable. 

To remain rational, with eyes open, still holding on to hope for those things too phenomenal to exist outside of fairy tales does not hurt anyone. If you consider a possibility, keep your eyes open for it, the greater the likelihood of its falling into your vision. Cynicism is nearly as ravenous as fear. Possibility. You see yourself, you see others. You look for that one whose eyes you like to be seen through. It's new but it's possible. There is, perhaps, the possibility, say, for someone to write on a page, If for no other reason than that it is a dreary night and I cannot concentrate beyond any page, I write this one to say that, perhaps if you were me for a moment, you might see yourself differently because, from my open eyes, you are rather exceptional and if you just Believe you will be able to accomplish anything your heart desires.

Lesson 6: Perseverance: - It pays off 

If you are among the EXTREMELY LUCKY few who get an e-mail reply from me, you should respect the fact I'm a little shy and probably won't give you my phone number right away, so don't nag me for it or try to make me feel like I'm a sissy because I haven't given it to you. 
We should develop a strong back-n-forth e-mail relationship through interesting and flirtatious (but not nauseating) "getting to know you" type conversation. And because I am shy about the phone, I will probably eventually opt to meet you for wine or dinner sometime. . . From this point we should both continue with exercises from Lesson 4, and assuming neither of us is hit by a bus or lapses into a coma by the time all necessary steps are complete, we'll both be in each others pants all over the place all of the time.

title: You totally want to read this
text:
I suppose in this section I am supposed to write all the qualities that make me amazing in an attempt to get people to read what I write and develop a sudden desire to talk to me. But let's face it, next to no one does that. Everyone views the pictures (if any) and skims through what was said and then decides from there. I have finally reached an age and a place in my life where I am through trying to coax people into interacting with me. With that being said let's get a couple things straight right off the bat. 

1.	No, I do not want to randomly hook up with you. (As cliché as this may sound it actually bares true)
2.	No, I do not want to Netflix and chill. Chill maybe because I am a hangout kind of guy, but this will consist of chilling somewhere outside of my house (preferably a park or movie or something)
3.	No, I am not looking for something casual or to be a part of your love triangle. (Old fashioned, enough said)
4.	No, I am not going to chase you down to talk to me. If interested talk to me, if not don't sit around waiting for me to always initiate the conversation. (will be waiting a long time, done playing this game)
Now with that out of the way let me say Hello (it's me, I've been wondering. . ..whoops, I digress haha) I try to inject humor into life, because what's a life without laughter.

Random Facts in no particular order about me:

I study hard so I can get a piece of paper that says I am smart.
I recently became an uncle (first time woo hoo)
I have a dog that I call monkey boy even though his name is not that.
Video games help me clear my head
Music works better
I talk a lot (sometimes a lot, a lot)
I listen more
I am average height
My eyes are boring brown so I sometimes use apps to make them look cool
Joel Barrish and Vince Vaughn are my spirit animals
I am planning on making a living giving people advice
A simple life makes me smile

There is a lot more to me but this is a simple snapshot of what I feel is important right now. As I evolve and change so does my life. People can either be a part of that or get out of the way. Your choice.

Rant over

title: Polyamory...?
text:
According to Wikipedia: "Polyamory is defined as is the practice, desire, or acceptance of having more than one intimate relationship at a time with the knowledge and consent of everyone involved."

I'll begin by saying this is a bit strange and theoretical, but if you are/have been curious I hope you'll indulge me a few minutes and give this slightly awkward posting a read. I should also say that I'm perhaps looking more for 'polyfidelity' than 'polyamory' (google it if you're interested), but I'm open. 

I'm a normal, reasonable, well adjusted and attractive guy with a life that is a little busier than ideal. That, and my experiences dating over the past year have sort of lead me to realization that looking for one 'significant other' to be what you want when you want (and vice-versa, of course) is a little bit limiting. You see, I've had several short but successful relationships with partners (girls, as I'm straight) who have been fun and interesting, but not 'everything' I was looking for in a partner or with a schedule that hasn't been compatible enough with mine to make things work. I realize this sounds particularly self-serving, but if you're still with me... what if you could find one partner who is some of what you're looking for, and another who is the rest, and you (either partner or both) could be together to the extent that time/interest allow?

Sounds almost too good to be true, which is of course why I cast this desire out unto the wilds of Craigslist. If you've ever found yourself in a similar situation, or maybe you're just a girl who likes guys AND girls, I'd love to hear from you.

And, thanks for reading.

title: Regarding my human
text:
Regarding my human:
Human female,
It seems I have come to an impass with my time. My human requires a companion. He has become quite bothersome to my plans of household destruction and/or domination; thwarting my efforts to conquer the entire space. That's where you come into my devious plan. I wish for you to distract my human; take him out of the dwelling for periods of time so that I may see my plans come to fruition. My human is very tall by my standard of measurement. His strength knows no bounds as he lifts me with such carefree ease (this could become a problem for me one day). He also flaps his gums at me often, making noises to request my presence, staring at me with his big brown eyes in the faint hope I am listening. I do enjoy his taste in moving images on this magic box though especially the games of throwing various objects around and into a yarn netting. This game intrigues me and I must admit is rather silly but alas, for some reason I cannot stop myself from following the objects with my eyes as their rapid movements around always stymie me for extended periods.

While he does feed me (when I tell him of course) and give me endless enjoyment of cleaning up after my droppings, and also practically worship me with his touch and petting several times a day, I do suppose he also requires some fulfillment apart from merely being my human.
Should you help me with my efforts I will grace your lap with my presence and purr to my satisfaction. This is by far the highest regard one can give.

Until then human,
Kitten~

This means I'm looking for a loving, caring, long term relationship with a single, funny, smart, educated woman with an irresistible charming personality, sense of adventure, and lots of common sense.

I love traveling, languages, experiencing different cultures and food, helping others, giving back to the community, continuously learning, cooking, music, all things outdoors, keeping fit, and others. title: MY CL Dating experience so far
text:
I've had several interesting experiences with the ladies in SF. I may not be stinking rich, but I'm sweet, cordial, independent and fit. SF is an interesting place, and I've met a whole lot of characters... 



The Rich Girl Wannabe 

This girl happens to be a walking billboard for Chanel, D&G, & LV. She drives a Mercedes SLK convertible. Everything looks perfect and you'd think I hit the jackpot? Wrong! Upon closer inspection, I find out she's a cashier at a clothing store and is just barely getting by because she's so maxed out on loans and credit cards. But hey, she looks like a million bucks. 



The Ambitious Lawyer 

Next date, I met this sharp, articulate Lawyer. Smart, stable, and got respect right? She tells me she hates her job and her life. Her parents pushed her into it, but she's making good dough now. Too bad she owes 250k to loans and she's working like a slave to the MAN. She has high spending standards, so it would be difficult for her to change careers. 



The Party Girl 

Nothing gets you jaded about love until you've met the Party Girl. I met her and fell like a ton of bricks. She's got a smoking body and a face like an angel. Unfortunately, four other suitors are also in love with her. She's playing everyone like a flute. Oh, almost forgot to mention about the cocaine habit. 



Biological Clock Girl 

This one didn't even reach the first date. I looked her up and we traded emails. I got her number and called her. The conversation felt like a job interview and I'm sure she has a checklist in front of her. Lady, you've gotta press the snooze button on that clock. 



The "I hate Asian Culture" Asian Girl 

I don't know what happened with her past relationships, but this girl hates anything that has to do with her own culture. Bitchier than Ling Woo, she tells me where to take her for dinner. White dudes, this one will be looking for you soon in the CL personals titled "SAF for SWM". 



The Drunk Christian 

Ok, I met this girl through friends and we all went to a club. I could tell that she was very attracted to me "like bees to honey" or was it because she had been drinking? I didn't care, I liked her because she seemed fun in a wacky way. A few days later, I asked for the number and she wouldn't give it to me because I was not Christian. W...T...F? Didn't Jesus hang out with prostitutes, thieves, and lepers? Well, next time I see her, I will be sure to bring along a six pack of beer. 



The Social Climber 

I went to a nightclub and met The Social Climber(s). You know, the ones that judge you from two questions, what do you do and how old are you. From the answer, they can tell everything about you like a psychic. If you don't answer doctor, lawyer, or banker, you will never get laid. 



The Amateur Goldigger 

Well, a girl contacted me after reading this post and she wanted to just be friends. I said, "sure", we could all use a new friend. I ask her out to meet at a friendly lunch and she requested that I pick her up and to also pay. Usually, I'm very generous with my friends and treating is not a problem. To ask me to pay in advance seems tacky, especially since we haven't met and it isn't a date. I had to cancel on this event. 



The Accidental Craigslister(s) 

I seem to be getting replies from women starting like this: "I was searching for a job, and I accidentally found your ad." or "I was bored, and somehow found your posting." or "I was selling my computer, and stumbled upon your ad." As if some computer virus possessed them to click on M4W and somehow prompted them write an email reply. It's OK to be on the internet searching for love. Many people have found their significant other to "complete them". It's OK to make a new friend through the net, trust me I'm completely harmless. 



SO WHAT AM I LOOKING FOR? 

How about some honest fun, conversation, and actual activity TONIGHT over a glass of something wonderful? I have my own place.How about you being a happy, emotionally stable, and loving person yourself? A sense of humor would be necessary, because I can be a wise-ass. Write to me.



PS: I am not bitter (actually optimistic). Do not think I hate women--actually love, respect and cherish them more than anything in the world. If I don't make fun of these people, I would go nuts. Also, I find my experience to be oddly educating and I hope you enjoyed them. =)

One day, up in the frozen north a polar bear and his son were out for a stroll. Daddy bear sat on a lump of ice to admire the view and sent his son off to play. Two minutes later Junior came back to dad and says, "Can I ask you a question dad?"

"Sure, son what is it?"

"Am I a real polar bear, Dad?" asks Junior.

Dad smiles and says, "Of course you are, son. Now go and play."

So off Junior goes again throws some snowballs at the seals but soon he's back.

title: Everyone's a cynic
text:
I'm somewhat new to San Francisco. I moved here for a new job and so far I love my new home. I find it really hard to meet women though. I'm a bit of an introvert so I hate going to bars and clubs, and I honestly have no idea where single women hang out. Comic book stores? Radio Shack? Knitting stores? (Disclaimer: I don't know anything about women). And I tried the SF Public Library but I'm not really into homeless women. So I thought I'd give Craigslist a try.

I'm a 36 year old SAM (single Asian male). I'm very easy-going and laid back with a sarcastic, self-deprecating sense of humor. I'm nerdy and probably not as clever as I think I am. I like traveling, photography, modern art, music, reading, sci-fi, graphic design, architecture, and looking for great hole-in-the-wall restaurants. I like urban hiking and exploring the nooks and crannies of the city. Please be around my age cause I like to make references to 80s pop culture.

And now some non sequiturs:

I have eclectic tastes in music (industrial, punk, post-punk, new wave).
I think sushi is overrated.
I like French New Wave films that I don't understand.
I had to look up "non sequitur" cause I wasn't quite sure what it means.
I love absurdist humor.
I read sci-fi, detective novels, and graphic novels.
I want to get a bicycle but I'm scared to death to ride on the street.
Spicy food gives me hiccups. Also seizures.
My favorite font is Univers.
I won a paper airplane contest in 2nd grade. It's been downhill ever since.
I have a pen and stationery fetish even though the most I write now is a post-it note.
I hate people who say "literally" and "I mean..."
I'm not on Facebook cause I'm a rebel.
I am on Google Plus cause I'm a contrarian.
I also had to look up "contrarian" in the dictionary cause I wasn't sure I was using it correctly.

Anyway, I'm attracted to intelligent, artistic, sarcastic, cynical women. I like the kind of girl who marches to the beat of her own drum. I'm looking for a woman who will watch movies with me on the couch, hang out with me in coffeeshops and look pretentious while secretly laughing at ourselves, ride a tandem bike and just hang out and be bored together on a Saturday night. Non-smokers only.

Write a clever subject so I know it's not spam. Your pic gets mine.

Pictures of my penis available upon request. Just kidding.

title: No time for a 24/7 relationship and perhaps you feel the same
text:
Hi. I'm not sure if anyone else is looking for something similar, but the honest reason I'm posting here on CL is because I am a busy professional with a great career and tend to work long hours. I find it not only hard to get out to meet women but also hard to keep a steady 24/7 relationship. Not many women understand the career oriented businessman and so I was hoping I'd meet someone with either the same aspirations or maybe pursuing a degree of some type. 

I'm a pretty good looking guy, the type you see and usually think he is already taken, open-minded and creative, funny, witty, smart, sarcastic and honestly, half the time outside of work I'm bored out of my mind. 

I'd love to take some time and share it with someone. Be able to meet regularly and maybe bring some intimacy to the relationship which we're not getting. I want someone who I can trust and understand so that the benefits don't get caught up into major drama. I'm not interested in marriage and not interested in a serious relationship. 

So let's start with a reply telling me a bit about yourself, what makes you tick, what you are looking for, and why a FWB relationship is something that interests you. Share a photo and let me know what your schedule is like. I'm off work for the rest of the week and maybe we could get together this evening and share in some fun. 

Looking forward to hearing from you.

title: Do you remember our first date?
text:
We meet on neutral ground and decide on something lighthearted and spontaneous, like seeing a foreign film and then writing "Occupy Hillsborough!" in the dust of parcel vans. 


You marvel at the variety of clutter in the back of my pickup and speculate whether it is sufficient to conceal a body. Seeing no blood or burial tools and lacking a portable luminol kit, you decide to proceed with the date, watchfully. 


At dinner, we argue the ethics of paid-access HOV lanes and speculate on the future of the Giants rotation, then proceed to debate California's long-term livability. Then, on to the merits (or lack thereof) of SF's subsidies of wealthy high-tech companies and why the sweetest dogs at the shelter tend to have the stereotypical "mean-looking" faces.


I argue that your preference for American League baseball and, worse yet, cricket, automatically renders your opinions on such matter inherently suspect. You argue (unsuccessfully) that you should get custody of my garlic bread because it is inappropriate fare while I am otherwise low-carbing; I counter that I deserve it because of my overall eating self-discipline justifies my keeping it, plus it's not like you were planning on kissing me tonight anyway. 



You wonder why if I'm such a Giants fan, I'm paying attention to you and not the road game currently blaring from the big screen. 



I reply that it's because I'm a genuinely thoughtful and attentive guy (not to mention humble!), I am taping the game and will watch it later. I'm silently marveling at your hair. 

You ridicule my usage of such primitive recording technology. 


I pretend to sulk, briefly. 


Your initial concern that I'm some sort of lunatic right-winger fades away as the conversation reveals that I am really more of a raving libertarian in principle. We banter examples of corruption at varying levels of government back and forth, which oddly mirrors your workday, having been spent observing coworkers evade productive tasks by tossing them back and forth without progress. I smile, knowlingly. 


You begin to reconsider the merits of my self-employment. I remind you of a key downside of self-employment: no cool company parties to which to take a date. 


You find the volume of iced tea I can put away in a day mildly disturbing, yet find it preferable to more immmediate concerns, such as my not being an axe murderer. 

At this point, your phone rings; it's your phony "emergency rescue" call from your girlfriend. You let her drop to voicemail, giving her a quick "I-think-I'm-getting-out-of-this-alive-and-having-fun-thanks-anyway" call back when I excuse myself to go to the mens' room. Iced tea, to the rescue. 


We proceed to the Animation Festival, where you only think to turn off your cellphone ringer as you see me do so to mine first. You drink half my iced tea after having just insisted, earlier, at the counter, that you were sure didn't want anything. You justify this to yourself by recalling at that damn iced tea I had at dinner and start a mental pool on how many times I will have to leave to pee (winner: zero). 


You pose as lookout while I strangle the punk in the row in front of us who couldn't keep off the damn cellphone. His body conveniently adheres to the sticky soda residue on the floor. 

This makes us feel oddly bonded.


Afterwards, we go for coffee. Your heart lightens a bit more as the scary-looking pit bull out front happily greets me and elicits a belly-rub and ear-scritch from me. You envision the potential advantages of a guy with such attention to detail. 


Inside, we order. I mock-ridicule the wimpiness of your latte; you feign shock that I order a Mocha Borgia rather than a keg of iced tea and a straw. We "split" a piece of cheesecake, though you have most of it, again in an attempt to protect me from the lurking carbohydrates. 

I pretend to sulk, briefly.

We even share a fork despite the epidemiological likelihood of exposure to cooties. 


We then part for the night; you are a bit surprised to find that I'm a better kisser than I had looked like I would be. Your relaxation at completing the night unmurdered and even ungroped is momentarily chilled by the concern that I didn't try to more explitictly move on you only because I'm gay or gutless. 

(Subsequent dates assuage that fear... but that's another story.) 


During the next few days, you are not sure how you feel. You cannot get me out of your head, not unlike a bad 1970s song that has lodged in a remote corner of your brain, or that last clump of lint that fell from the lint screen down into the dark recesses of dryer's interior, forever out of reach. 


We spend a subsequent Saturday going on a railroad hike and a long drive. I arrive in a different car, given that I tend to get the cheap car rentals on weekends where I do a lot of driving, such as weekends when I can have a lots of errands. After all, the free unlimited mileage could just as easily be for an cost-effective out-of-town crime spree. 


You don't even feel the need to inspect the trunk for shovels and bodybags first. 


We drive, we hike, you steal my water and trail mix. We stop by a place with old arcade games and play cheesy video games from our childhoods. You marvel at my pinball skill. You beat me at Defender, never feeling the familiar fear that I'm going to feel my male ego compromised by losing. 

I pretend to sulk, briefly. 


We drive on to that reknowned BBQ place in Castroville but find it closed, instead settling for tri-tip at Cole's. This time, I even let you have my garlic bread, subsequently even kissing you anyway. 


You come to find that nice guys aren't so bad after all. 



SWM, 52, south bay native (yeah, I'm the one), 6'. 



Please include a pic of you doing something you enjoy. [Unless that "something" is some other guy.]
